Name: p-CRESOL
Description: P-cresol is a cresol that consists of toluene substituted by a hydroxy group at position 4. It is a metabolite of aromatic amino acid metabolism produced by intestinal microflora in humans and animals. It has a role as a uremic toxin, a human metabolite and an Escherichia coli metabolite.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Fiege H; Cresols and Xylenols. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 7th ed. (1999-2014). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: Jun 15, 2000.
plant_concentrations.Value: Cresols, including p-cresol, are widespread in nature occurring in many plants and trees(1). Cresols occur in various plant lipid constituents, including oils from jasmine, cassia and Easter lily, ylang ylang, and Yucca gloriosa flowers, peppermint, eucalyptus, and camphor. Oils from conifers, oaks, and sandalwood trees also contain cresols(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Lebedev AT et al; Sci Total Environ 212: 153-62 (1998)
animal_concentrations.Value: p-Cresol concentrations of 5.6 to 540 ug/kg dry wt were detected in the birds eggs collected from the Lake Baikal region (Selenga River estuary, Russia)(1).

Available from, as of Jan 5, 2015: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 9 was calculated for p-cresol(SRC), using a log Kow of 1.94(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF value suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Chudoba J et al; SB.VYS Sk Chem Technol Praze Technol Vody 13: 45-63 (1968) (2) Smith JH et al; Environ Pathways of Selected Chemicals in Freshwater Systems Part II Lab Studies USEPA-600/7-78-074 (1978) (3) Rogers JE et al; Microbial Transformation Kinetics of Xenobiotics in Aquatic Environ p 105 USEPA-600/3-84-043 (1984) (4) Van Veld PA, Spain JC; Chemosphere 12: 1291-305 (1983) (5) Spain JC, Van Veld PA; Appl Environ Microbiol 45: 428-35 (1983) (6) Goerlitz DF et al; Environ Sci Technol 19: 955-61 (1985) (7) Loehr RC; Treatability Potential For EPA Listed Hazardous Wastes In Soil. USEPA Robert S Kerr Environ Res Lab, ADA, OK USEPA/600/2-89/011 (1989) (8) Desai S et al; Determination of Monod Kinetics of Toxic Compounds by Respirometry for Structure-biodegradability Relationships ACS Symp Ser (Emerging Technol Hazard Waste Manage) 142-156 (1989) (9) Dawson TD, Chang FH; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 49: 10-17 (1992) (10) OECD; SIDS Initial Assessment Report For SIAM 16, m-Cresol (CAS No. 108-39-4) and p-Cresol (CAS No. 106-44-5), May 30, 2003). Available from, as of Jan 5, 2015: https://www.chem.unep.ch/irptc/sids/OECDSIDS/m-p-cresols.pdf
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Complete degradation of p-cresol was obtained in a simulated biological treatment plant in 16-74 hours(1). p-Cresol biodegrades rapidly in environmental waters including oligotrophic lakes, eutrophic ponds, rivers, creeks and bays(2-5). Total degradation occurred in Lake Tahoe, CA water within 6 days and 4 days depending on whether the water contained sediment or not, respectively(2). In a eutrophic pond, degradation was complete in 7-8.5 hr after a 5.5-6 hr lag period(2). The half-life of p-cresol in two fish ponds ranged from 2-7 hr after a 30-56 hr lag(3). In 3 river waters of the Pacific North West, the half-life of p-cresol ranged from 1-10 hr after a 2 day lag period(3). At 3 sites in Pensacola Bay, FL the half-life of p-cresol ranged from 9-43 hr in salt water(4). In marine water/sediment cores from 3 Pensacola Bay sites, biodegradation half-lives ranged from 3-16 hr(4). 95% of the p-cresol added to fresh water/sediment cores from the Escamba River, FL degraded in 75 hr and 22% was mineralized in that period(5). The disproportionate decrease in the concentration of p-cresol in groundwater down-gradient from a wood preserving facility has been ascribed to biodegradation(6). Biodegradation half-lives of 1 and 0.5 days were reported for p-cresol in 2 agricultural soils(7). The first-order aerobic biodegradation rate constant of p-cresol was reported as 0.0029/day(8), corresponding to a half-life of about 239 days(SRC). Pure cultures isolated from reed-sedge peat bogs resulted in 97.7% degradation of p-cresol during a 40 hour incubation period(9). Based upon available test results, including OECD screening methods, p-cresol can be considered as being readily biodegradable under aerobic conditions(10).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Boyd SA et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 46: 50-4 (1983) (2) Shelton DR, Tiedje JM; Appl Environ Microbiol 47: 850-7 (1984) (3) Horowitz A et al; Dev Ind Microbiol 23: 435-44 (1982) (4) Battersby NS, Wilson V; Appl Environ Microbial 55: 433-39 (1989) (5) Van Veld PA, Spain JC; Chemosphere 12: 1291-305 (1983)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: Under anaerobic conditions, p-cresol was mineralized in 3 and 8 weeks in two screening studies using digester sludge inocula(1,2). However, no mineralization was observed when incubated for 29 weeks in anaerobic sediment from the pelagic region of hypereutrophic Wintergreen Lake in Kalamazoo County, MI(3). The half-life of p-cresol in an anaerobic digester sludge was 18.5 days(4). At 3 sites in Pensacola Bay, FL the half-life of p-cresol ranged from 6-11 hrs when anaerobic sediment was added to the water(5).

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 32

sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: p-Cresol was identified, not quantified, in the soil of an abandoned pine tar manufacturing plant in Gainesville, FL(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Lopes TJ et al; pp 105-19 in Environ Toxicol Risk Assess: Seventh Volume, ASTM STP 1333, Little EE et al, eds., Amer Soc Testing Materials (1997) (2) Schwarzbauer J et al; Org Geochem 31: 1713-31 (2000)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: p-Cresol was detected in 215 out of 370 bed sediment samples collected in the US during a 1992-1995 national surveillance study(1). The median, mean and maximum concentartions of p-cresol in these samples were 53, 210, and 3500 ug/kg, respectively(1). p-Cresol was identified, not quantified, in sediment samples obtained from the Elbe River, Germany(2).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) ECHA; Search For Chemicals. p-Cresol (CAS No. 106-44-5) Registered Substances Dossier. Full. European Chemical Agency. Available from, as of Jan 5, 2015:  (2) Artiola-Fortuny J, Fuller WH; Soil Sci 133(1): 18-26 (1982) (3) Shiu WY et al; Chemosphere 29: 1155-1244 (1994) (4) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) https://echa.europa.eu/
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: A Koc of 49 was measured for o-cresol in a Brookston clay loam soil using OECD Guideline 106(1). Based on measured Freundlich isotherms for p-cresol in five different horizon soils (organic content of 0.3 to 0.9%)(2), the Koc ranged from 27 to 251 with an average of 173(SRC). Other reported Koc values include a Koc of 500 in soil and 645 in a sediment(3). According to a classification scheme(4), these Koc values indicate that p-cresol is expected to have very high to moderate mobility in soil.
